Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Hyperinsulinemic Normoglycemia in Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: dual-center, parallel-group, superiority trial randomized cardiac surgical patients

Participants.evidence: cardiac surgical patients at the Cleveland Clinic and Royal Victoria Hospital

Intervention.evidence: hyperinsulinemic normoglycemia (fixed high-dose insulin and variable glucose infusion targeting 80–110 mg·dL−1) or standard glycemic management (low-dose insulin targeting glucose >150 mg·dL−1)

Objective.evidence: This study tested whether it reduces 30-day mortality and morbidity post-cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was a composite of 30-day mortality, mechanical circulatory support, infection, renal or neurologic morbidity.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1,439 patients were randomized (709 to hyperinsulinemic normoglycemia, 730 to standard management).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome occurred in 49 (6.9%) patients in the hyperinsulinemic group versus 82 (11.2%) in the standard group (P<0.0085); relative risk 0.62 (95% CI 0.39, 0.97), P=0.0043.

Harms.evidence: Severe hypoglycemia (<40 mg·dL−1) occurred in 6 (0.9%) patients.
